Although it is evident that there is damage in various organs such as the liver, kidneys and lymphoid tissue, viral antigens are only detected in the liver. According to Engelmann et al .
42 , these observations provide new information on the yellow fever pathogenesis, suggesting that the kidney and the lymphoid tissue damage may not be directly mediated by in situ viral replication, probably occurring through soluble mediators that could be potentially produced elsewhere
42 .
